Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Archaeological Investigations at Surtshellir Cave
Award.AbstractNarration:
Caves were places of fear for the Norse colonies of the North Atlantic, and were generally avoided. One notable exception is Surtshellir cave, one of the largest lava-tube caves in the world. Surtshellir's folklore, mythology, and historic narratives span nearly a millennium and are dominated by images of terror, the overthrow of the world's order, and the restoration of balance through the actions of Viking Age chieftains and community leaders. These stories begin with the being for whom the cave is named - Surtur, an elemental force of fire and lava whom the Norse believed was present at the world's creation and would destroy the world, men, and the gods at the end of time. Surtshellir has an impressive archaeological record, documented by the PI on expeditions into Surtshellir in 2001 and, with NSF EAGER funding, in 2012: a ship-shaped Viking Age structure 300 meters back into the cave, massive numbers of dismembered, intentionally fragmented animal bones, and a dry-stone wall 30 ft (10 m) long and 15ft (4.5 m) high built to block entrance or exit from the cave.

Two explanations have been put forward for Surtshellir's unique archaeological record: that these are the residues of outlaws' occupations or that it represents a site at which sacrifices were made to calm Surt or to prevent the end of the world. Assessing these alternatives will lead to major refinements of our understanding of Viking Age religion and the social and sacral organization that the North Atlantic Norse colonizers brought with them, or developed on arriving in Iceland. Central to understanding this site are thin floor deposits within the Viking Age structure that the PI?s team identified in 2012. However, the site is now a tourist destination and these fragile Viking Age deposits and their artifacts are being damaged and looted by unregulated access to the cave and ultimately endangered by the ongoing collapse of the cave's roof, both of which limit the time when the site can be documented.

The PI will use RAPID funding in August 2013 to excavate these endangered cultural deposits before another tourist season can damage them further or the roof's collapse seals them forever. The project's international collaborators - the National Museum of Iceland and theIcelandic Antiquities Office view this research as a necessary first step towards protecting the site's archaeological resources, interpreting it for present and future generations, and enabling sustainable and justifiable tourist access to the cave.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored a unique Viking Age site within a cave in a lava field in Iceland's western interior highlands. Nearly 800 feet from the entrance, in total darkness lies a roofless, stone, boat-shaped structure and piles of fragmented bone. Folklore surrounding the site and brief mentions in medieval Icelandic documents connect the site variously with outlaws or with Surtur, an elemental being who Viking Age Icelanders believed would bring about the end of the world: the name Surtshellir means, in fact, Surtur's Cave. Surtshellir formed during a massive eruption that began shortly after Iceland's first settlers arrived from Scandinavia. This was quite likely the first volcanic eruption that Northern Europeans had ever directly observed. It buried 93 square miles of fertile grazing and farmland and perhaps 5-6 farms beneath lava, while splitting a glacier and boiling away two rivers, creating major impacts on the landscape and on early Icelanders' views of nature and religion.

In 2013, with NSF funding, our multi-national team from Brown University, the National Museum of Iceland, and the Icelandic Archaeological Heritage Agency excavated thin floor deposits within the boat-shaped structure before they could be damaged or destroyed by unregulated tourist visits or collapse of the cave's roof. In 2012, during a previous NSF-funded mapping project, we had discovered Viking Age beads disturbed from these thin floor deposits, which had been considered natural and sterile. Excavation in 2013 determined, instead, that these deposits were intentionally created by crushing basalt from the cave's walls and using them as a low surface on which to build intensely hot fires where animal bones were burned, cooked, or cremated as offerings. The artifacts found within this thin deposit, along with survey of the cave system, helped us to evaluate two competing hypotheses: that the cave had served as the residence of an outlaw band or that it had been a place of ritual linked to the eruptions and efforts to prevent further destruction by sacrificing animals, presumably to Surtur.

To assess the "outlaw occupation" hypothesis, we sought evidence of areas where torches had burned to light the cave's total darkness, fires had been maintained to warm it, where food had been cooked, water had been stored, and human waste had accumulated. To assess the "ritual" hypothesis, we examined whether the objects found at the site were those expected at a residential site or matched the kinds of offerings found at other Norse sacred sites. We used volumetric reconstructions and soil micro-morphological analyses to estimate the amounts of wood and bone burned at the site, allowing us to evaluate whether those amounts could have sustained a resident group or represented episodic or repeated, but short-lived ritual acts. 

Our survey revealed no areas with deposits that matched our expectations for residential activity (i.e. no areas of soot staining from torches, no piles of ash from fires, etc.). In contrast, excavation of the boat-shaped structure's thin floor deposits suggested a repeated series of very specific actions. Small but extremely hot fires were made periodically at the center of the structure by people who had come from potentially great distances to do so.
